title: How to Protect Your RFID Credit Card

steps.title: Place your RFID cards next to each other in your wallet.
steps.content: Place your RFID cards next to each other in your wallet. This can make it more difficult for thieves to read a particular card, but the protection is limited. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Carry your RFID cards in a front pocket.
steps.content: Carry your RFID cards in a front pocket. If you usually carry your credit cards in a wallet in your back pocket, you are potentially more vulnerable to thieves who could step up behind you with a scanning device. If you switch the cards to a front pocket, you will tend to be more observant of people in front of you and are less likely to become a victim. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Be aware of other people around you when using your credit cards.
steps.content: Be aware of other people around you when using your credit cards. Some of the newest RFID technology limits the opportunity of thieves to scan your cards to short distances and only at the time of the sale. [3] X Research source Before using your card in a store, check around you to make sure that nobody is standing within a few feet of you, and your transaction should be safe.

steps.title: Use your RFID cards at home for online purchases only.
steps.content: Use your RFID cards at home for online purchases only. If you are really concerned by the RFID technology, this is a possible way to go, and you can then use other credit cards or cash to purchase things outside your home. However, identity theft through online computer use is probably a greater risk than using the RFID technology in a store. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Monitor your credit card statements for usual activity or errors.
steps.content: Monitor your credit card statements for usual activity or errors. This may not actually prevent thieves from stealing information from your card, but monitoring your statements regularly will help you and the credit card company identify any unauthorized purchases and can limit your potential losses. [5] X Research source Some sources say that regular monitoring of your credit card statements is actually the “best” protection against identity theft. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Purchase an RFID shield wallet or sleeve for credit cards.
steps.content: Purchase an RFID shield wallet or sleeve for credit cards. There are several commercial products available that claim to block RFID scanners from obtaining your personal information. These may be individual sleeves for your RFID cards or wallets that are lined with material to block scanners. [7] X Research source on/#are-they-secure

steps.title: Purchase an RFID jamming card or device.
steps.content: Purchase an RFID jamming card or device. Some companies have developed a device about the size of a credit card that sends out its own RFID signal that will disrupt scanners trying to get your credit card information. [8] X Research source [9] X Research source

steps.title: Make a foil shield.
steps.content: Make a foil shield. This is the “low-tech” way to go, but it’s cheap and easy. Cut two pieces of paper or cardboard into the size of a credit card, wrap each piece with aluminum foil, and carry them in your wallet around your credit cards. The aluminum will disrupt most electronic signals. [10] X Research source

steps.title: You can also wrap each credit card in aluminum foil and place the wrapped cards in your wallet.
steps.content: You can also wrap each credit card in aluminum foil and place the wrapped cards in your wallet. The foil shields the card from scanners. [11] X Research source

Verify that vendors you use online are legitimate. Stick to vendors that you have used before and that you know and trust. If you have concerns, you can check with the Better Business Bureau online at https://www.bbb.org/ or in the local area where the company has its business.

steps.title: Look for signs of a "secure" website.
steps.content: Look for signs of a "secure" website. Truly secure websites use extra protection called a Secure Sockets Layer, or SSL, and the website address will begin with "https" instead of the usual "http." Additionally, a secure site will show a closed lock icon in the status bar at the bottom of the page. If you don't see the "https" address or the padlock at the bottom, you should consider using another website for your purchase. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Maintain your own computer.
steps.content: Maintain your own computer. For safer online shopping, keep your own computer free of viruses or spyware. There are software products you can purchase or download online for free that will help you keep your computer clean. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Limit Wi-Fi purchasing.
steps.content: Limit Wi-Fi purchasing. Because anything wireless is potentially subject to hackers who find a way to intercept the radio signal, your safest method for online shopping is to use a hardwired Internet connection.

steps.title: Use a temporary credit card for online shopping.
steps.content: Use a temporary credit card for online shopping. Many banks and credit companies will offer this service for no fee. You can get a card number that is separate from your actual account, but the bank links it to your account for your bona fide purchases.
